texts.en: Jamie B. is twenty-seven years old and has four children. Jamie started her business three years ago selling saucepans and palm oil in front of  her house.  She goes to the villages to purchase palm oil in bulk in “gerri cans” and distributes them to retailers in the neighborhood.   She would like a loan of $250 to purchase fourteen more “gerri cans” of palm oil.

loans.use: to increase her inventory to distribute wholesale to local retailers

loans.name: Sreng

texts.en: Mrs. Sreng C., age 47, is a widow and sells grocery products in the market, earning up to $10 per day in revenue. She has three children; one child sells food and rice on the roadside, making about $1.50 each day in profit, and two children work as waiters in a restaurant. In order to expand her inventory of grocery items to meet her clients’ demands, she would like to borrow $1,200 to purchase a greater variety of products to resell.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of grocery products to increase inventory

loans.name: Bihol

texts.en: Bihol I. has good profitable stand at the fabrics market in Istaravshan, Khujand. She has been in business for over 15 years. She has good experience and sells her goods skillfully. She has a lot of repeat customers and her fabrics are more competetive than others'. She perfectly understands her customers' needs and she always helps to her customers to choose fabrics. Now she also sells traditional dresses from a local workshop which sews dresses from her fabrics. She is planning to purchase warm, high-quality fabrics for winter and she needs a loan of US$ 475 to be able to do so.

loans.use: Purchase warm fabrics appropriate to the season

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es:
Maritza is a member of the Los Jazmines Communal Bank and lives in the province and district of Moyobamba in San Martin. She has a stand in the city’s central market where she sells fruits and vegetables from the coast. She decided to start this business because she wanted to be independent financially and with her time, and because she previously had a salaried job and she didn’t like being subjected to a boss and a schedule. Because she is a very apt and hard-working person, and because she likes to manage her own capital, she decided to start this activity and in that way, grow as a person and a woman.

The loan of S./ 1,000.00, which she will repay in 6 months, will buy her fruits such as apples, mangoes and peaches in boxes as well as vegetables like potatoes, onions, sweet potatoes in sacks, cauliflower, red peppers, spinach by the kilo and other fruits and vegetables. In that way, she will keep her sales stand well-stocked and her customers happy.

Maritza is 41 years old and has no children, but she is raising 4 nieces and nephews who can now support her in her business and at home. She also counts with the support of her husband. She is happy with what she does and with the results she has obtained to date. Her clientele has increased, which also helped improve her financial situation. Her goal is to have her business at home so that she may tend to her business and her household at the same time.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maritza es socia del banco comunal Los Jazmines, vive en el Jr. Grau s/n c-4 de la provincia y distrito de Moyobamba, departamento de San Martín. Tiene un puesto en el mercado central de la ciudad donde vende frutas y verduras de la costa. Decidió iniciarse en el negocio porque quería ser independiente en tiempo y dinero y porque antes tenía un trabajo con un sueldo y no le gustaba estar sujeto a un jefe y a un horario. Como ella es una persona muy trabajadora y hábil y como le gusta manejar su propio capital decidió iniciar esta actividad y de esa manera poder crecer como persona y mujer.

El préstamo de 1,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará frutas como manzanas, mangos, duraznos en cajas, verduras como papas, cebollas, camotes en sacos, coliflor, ají pimentón, espinaca en kilos y demás frutas y verduras y de esa manera tener bien surtido su puesto de venta y también tener bien satisfechos a sus clientes.

Tiene 41 años, no tiene hijos, pero está criando a cuatro sobrinos quienes ahora ya la apoyan en el negocio y en la casa, también cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo. Está contenta con lo que hace y satisfecha con los resultados obtenidos hasta la fecha, su clientela aumentó y ello también ayudó a que mejore su situación económica. Su meta es contar con un negocio en su casa para poder estar pendiente a la vez de su casa y negocio.

loans.use: Purchase fruits (apples, mangoes, peaches, etc.) and  vegetables (potatoes, onions, sweet potatoes, cauliflower, red peppers and spinach)

loans.name: Libbis

texts.en:
Libbis E. L. has a business manufacturing and selling bed spreads in the city of Juanjui, San Martin.  She started the business one year ago with $50 and her sewing machine.  Libbis had a lifetime of business experience but never a business of her own.  She sells her handmade bed spreads in the main market of Juanjui and door to door in the surrounding rural towns.  

The business has given her a new lease on life.  She is 48, married, has 3 children and happier than ever.  She has gained confidence, independence, and a voice in her community.  She has made many new friends and is more well known in the different communities.  Her children have more opportunities and live in a healthier environment.  Now the entire family dreams of a better life.

Libbis is a member of the community bank Micaela Bastidas and is requesting a loan of $350 to repay over 4 months.  She will use the loan to buy thread and materials of many different patterns and colors.

loans.use: To buy thread and materials of many different patterns and colors

loans.name: Patricia María

texts.en: Patricia is thirty-six years old and an excellent entrepreneur. She sells men’s and women’s clothing in the Batey of Palavé community of San Cristobal. She explains with enthusiasm that her business is very promising, since she has a growing clientele. Patricia plans to boost her business and add a wide variety of new clothing to her present inventory. That way, she’ll increase her sales volume and attract new clients. The entrepreneur has five children, four of them boys, all of whom attend school. Her business supports their educations.

loans.use: Patricia would like to buy clothing wholesale in order to increase her sales volume.

loans.name: Rocío

texts.es:
Rocío is a very young woman. Regardless, at 25 years old, she manages her business very well. As a result of her marriage, she realized that it was necessary to have an additional source of income apart from that of her husband's since it was not enough to have only one of them cover their living expenses. Once she knew that she was pregnant, she decided to open a business in the market. Currently, she has already had 8 months of business selling clothes at her stall. Despite the new born baby who is a few months old, she works daily at her job. She does not believe the baby is an inconvenience; rather, th baby gives her strength everyday to leave for work. Later on, Rocío would like to have a store in the commercial district.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Translator.

Rocío es una mujer joven; no obstante, a sus veinticinco años, maneja muy bien su negocio. A raíz de que casó vio la necesidad de tener una fuente adicional a su hogar a parte de la que tenía su esposo, pues muchas veces no era suficiente con el trabajo de uno de los dos para cubrir los gastos de la casa. Una vez que supo que estaba embarazada decidió abrir un negocio en el mercado y actualmente ya tiene ocho meses atendiendo en su puesto de ropa. A pesar de tener un bebe de pocos meses de nacido ella asiste diariamente a sus labores de trabajo. Ella no cree esto un inconveniente pues es precisamente su bebe quien le da fuerzas todos los días para salir a trabajar. Mas adelante a Rocío le gustaría poner un local en un centro comercial.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Heleni

texts.en:
Mambo (hello!) from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Heleni M.. She is single and has two children, ages 6 months and 13 years.

In 1999, Heleni established her rice farming business. Heleni requires a loan in order to plant, harvest, and sell more rice. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a leading role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. Because customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, the women lack tangible collateral assets, and financial institutions do not consider them to be credit-worthy. This leads to poor financial support and, as a result, limited access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys the equipment from the client, extends a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a "sale and leaseback" arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase supplies and equipment for her rice farm.

loans.name: Khelcom 2 A Group

texts.fr: Our ecovillage is located in an area frequented by tourists who all go to a town very far away from our ecovillage to connect to the internet. The same thing happens with the young people in our village who also go to the town looking to connect to the internet. Since there is great demand for the internet, we would like to ask for your help in creating a cybercafé in the village which would fill the current gap in information technology in our area. Ever since our village got wired for electricity and connected to the telephone network, we have been looking to open a cybercafé, not only in order to create jobs, but to take part in the development of our locality by allowing the populace access to information via modern communication technology. For this reason we have established two groups, each having the same objective. Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteerNotre écovillage se trouve dans une zone touristique qui voit toutes les personnes qui y viennent se  rendre dans une ville très éloignée de notre écovillage pour se connecter à Internet. c'est la même situation qui se répète pour les jeunes du village qui empruntent la même voie pour avoir accès à une connection. La demande étant très forte à ce sujet, nous venons solliciter votre appui afin que nous puissions créer un cybercafé dans le village et permettant ainsi de combler le gap numérique qui existait dans les environs. Depuis que notre village est connecté aux réseaux électrique et téléphonique, nous oeuvrons dans le sens de créer un cybercafé pour non seulement créer des emplois, mais participer aussi au développement de notre localité en aidant les populations à avoir accès à l'information avec les nouvelles technologies de comunication modernes. pour cela nous nous sommes constitués en deux groupement avec chacun le même objectif.

loans.use: Purchase of computers and other equipment for cybercafeAchat d'ordinateurs et équipements pour cybercafé

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea Y., 52, is married and lives with four of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$1 each day and are supported by three children working in the garment factory. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Chea Y. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$200 to purchase fertilizer. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Mayo B 2004-1 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Nura Sadeya. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and vegetables at the market and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Nura is 40 years old and is married with a husband who is a policeman. She has 2 children aged 15 and 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Nura makes approximately 50 Sudanese pounds in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

Nura is joined in her small group by R. Sayama, Poni Susan, Labany R., and Mary Sammuel. R. Sayama has a business selling charcoal and wants to buy charcaol for sale. Poni Susan is currently operating a business selling cosmetics at a shop and wants a loan to open up restaurant. Labany R. operates a business selling charcoal and wants to open a clinic. Mary Sammuel is currently in the business of selling at a shop and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji is the wife of J. H.. She lives in the small city of Chichawatni, Pakistan. She is the mother of nine children: seven sons and two daughters. Sakina's baji's elder son has a wood business. The next eldest son has a grocery shop. Her younger son is a daily wage laborer. Sakina baji and her daughters prefer to stay at home and do household work. Sakina baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a Pakistan microfinance institute). She invested the loan amount in her son's grocery shop. Now she is applying for a loan to buy groceries to diversify her son's grocery shop into a grocery store.

Sakina baji is joined in her loan group by four other members. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy shoes for her shoe selling business. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy leather to resell. Muniran baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Shahida baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Tran Thi H. joined TYM Fund in 2006. Before this turning point, she encountered many financial difficulties as she had a lot of children but lacked capital to do business other than basic farming and livestock raising. After borrowing from TYM, her family had capital to buy materials for mat weaving. Thanks to the loan, she had more mats to sell and her family's income increased steadily. With an income of VND 3 million per month, her family's economy is better now and more stable. She wants to borrow VND 7 million to buy more materials to weave mats.

loans.use: Tran would like to buy more materials to weave mats to sell.

loans.name: Nazokat

texts.en:
U. Nazokat is the 52-year-old loving mother of three children. The elder son is already a student and the younger children are going to school. Nazokat and her husband, who bakes the bread, dream that all three of their children will receive higher education.

For 13 years, Nazokat has had a business selling the national bread “lepeshka” in the local market in the city of Khujand. The bread is the main dish on any table. That is why Nazokat’s business is rather successful and stable. She has had buyers who purchase in bulk for many years, which provides her with a stable income for her family.

Nazokat requests a loan of $600 USD to purchase more bread in order to increase the variety of goods that she offers. She promises to repay the loan in 6 months. One of her dreams is that her children will improve their quality of life by studying. She makes great sacrifices so she can send them to college. Let’s support this woman who has a lot of courage and strength to have a better life.

loans.use: Purchase bread to increase variety of bread to sell

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma A. was born in 1981 and she is from Visoka, a village in Bosnia. She is married and has a 6-year-old child. Her husband has a business as a carpenter, and sells custom-made wood products in the local market. Alma helps her husband in his woodshop, and also grows vegetables (potatoes, onions and carrots) which she sells for about 150KM/month (the equivalent of roughly $100USD/month).

Alma requests a loan of 600KM from Women for Women International, which she will use to buy raw materials for the woodshop.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for a woodshop.

loans.name: Djidéré

texts.fr: Djidéré D., 54 ans, mariée, 07 enfants et 04 petits fils en charge est membre du banc villageois de Vélingara  Maréwé depuis 2 ans et demi. Elle veut acheter des légumes, de l’huile de palme et des produits alimentaires divers pour renforcer son commerce. Le prêt qu'elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Djidéré D., age 54, is married and has seven children and four grandchildren to look after. She has been a member of the village loan group Vélingara Maréwé for two and a half years. She wants to buy vegetables, palm oil, and various grocery items to bolster her business. The loan she is requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in vegetables, palm oil, grocery items

loans.name: Central B1-Baluka Betty Group

texts.en:
Betty B. is 45 years of age. She is a widow and a devoted mother of seven children. She is also a caring guardian to two orphans, a niece and a nephew. Betty sells bogoya (ripe bananas) in Kabalagala market. She purchases her stock twice a week from suppliers who source the fruit from Masaka. From stock worth 800,000 (about USD $450) Betty expects a profit of 150,000 shillings.

Based on her 10 years' experience in the business, she attracts and retains customers by being friendly, charming, selling fresh healthy fruits and also by maintaining high standards of cleanliness. She will use this loan to add to her stock of bogoya to increase her income.

Betty has a great ambition: she aspires to be an exporter of fresh fruits to developed countries. Her desire is a peaceful and prosperous family.

Betty will share this loan the other four members of her group.

loans.use: To purchase bogoya ( ripe bananas).

loans.name: Trab

texts.en:
Mr. T., born in 1978 and currently living in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, earns a living as a local building worker, making on average $3 per day, to help feed the family. Married to Hak Ly, 26, who cultivates rice and raises pigs, the couple is responsible for two young children, both attending school.

To earn additional income and enhance the success of his wife’s business, Mr. T. is requesting a $300 loan to purchase piglets to raise and rice to store for later sale, as well as some ingredients for distilling wine.

T.'s wife is pictured, as T. was unavailable.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise.

loans.name: Kossivi Eric

texts.fr:
A. éric habite le quartier  de soviépé et à une boutique de prêt-à-porter qu’il  appelle  
‘’Prêt-à-porter ERIC’’, il a commencé ce commerce en 2006 et cela lui réussit bien, les jeunes de l’homme aime beaucoup le look c’est pour celà qu’il a entamé ce commerce, il veut agrandir son stock c’est pour cela qu’il sollicite un crédit de 500000F pour s’acheter des vêtements féminin et masculin.il est marié et a 04 enfants.
texts.en:
Eric A. lives in the Soviépé district and has a shop selling ready-to-wear clothing. “Prêt-à-porter ERIC” is the name of his shop, a business he started in 2006 that has been successful for him. Young men like to be in style a lot. That’s why he started in this commerce. He wants to expand his inventory, so he is requesting a loan of 500,000 francs to buy clothing for women and men. Eric is married and has four children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing for men and women

loans.name: Mariarosa

texts.en:
Mariarosa A., 55, is married with 2 children. She has 2 years of experience in a vegetables business. She sells to the village people and the general public 3 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (approximately $166 USD).

SPBD loans are Mariarosa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used buy chemicals, pesticides and a wheel barrow, and to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals, pesticides, a wheel barrow, machetes and her children's school fees.

loans.name: Zahooran Allah Wasaya Group

texts.en:
Zahooran baji is a widow and resides in a city named Vehari, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it with her three children (two daughters and one son) for the past 10 years. With the income from her clothes-sewing business she put her daughters into school and started a shoe-selling business for her son. Her family is very happy and give her respect and feel proud. Zahooran baji is applying for a loan to buy a stock of shoes for her son’s shoe-selling business.

Zahooran baji is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Sahabzadi baji wants a loan to repair her 32-seat local bus. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Zakia baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business. Ata Ilahi baji wants a loan to change the body of her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a stock of shoes for her son’s shoe-selling business

loans.name: Marleny Yanet

texts.es:
Marleny es socia del Banco Comunal Rikchary que significa Despierta en quechua.
Marleny es soltera, tiene 29 años y 1 hijo, Marleny tiene un puesto en el mercado central de la ciudad de Ayacucho en donde vende verduras, además por las tardes vende golosinas de manera ambulatoria en el parque de la ciudad.
Marleny necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de golosinas variadas.
Los sueños de Marleny son mejorar su negocio y construir su casa.
texts.en:
Marleny is a member of the Communal Bank "Rikchary," which means, "Awake" in Quechua. Marleny is 29 years old, single, and has a son. Marleny has a place in the central market in the city, Ayacucho, where she sells vegetables. She also sells sweets in the afternoons around the city park. Marleny needs a loan of 1200 soles that she will invest in buying a variety of sweets. Marleny has dreams of improving her business and building a home.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Para la compra de golosinas variadas.

loans.name: Adebayo

texts.en: Adebayo K. A. is 38 years old and married with 4 children. Adebayo has two motorcycles that he uses to convey passengers from one location to another within his community in Oyo town. He is requesting a loan in the amount of N50, 000 to purchase one motorcycle to enable him meet the demands of his customers. He says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase one motorcycle

loans.name: Kwakye

texts.en:
Kwakye A. is forty -five years old. He is married and has six children. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase. Kofiase is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region.

Kwakye says his children are in junior high and primary school. His wife is a petty trader. He is also a petty trader. He runs a cold store in his community. Kwakye says his cold store is located at the market square. He sells fresh fish, beef, chicken, turkey, etc. He wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to increase his stock. Kwakye has been in business for two years. He is hopeful to expand his business and improve his standard of living. He is hopeful to give his children a sound education.

loans.use: To procure fresh fish and meat

loans.name: Basilia

texts.en:
Basila began her business of selling plastic wares six years ago with only a few items. Before receiving a loan she worked as a trash collector for the city. Fueled by her desire to succeed, she joined her local Committee of Women and benefited greatly from the support of her neighbors and friends. After four years, she felt secure in her business and left the Committee to receive individual credit. 

Today, Basila’s plastics shop is filled with a wide range of goods and she is happy to service a large clientele. Her daughter often works with her and her son owns his own electronics shop in the center of the city. Although her work has long hours and isn’t easy, she is proud to own her shop and has aspirations to continue to make her business better.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Leonardo

texts.en:
To have an abundant harvest and own some farm machinery are the ultimate goals of Leonardo B., a farmer and father of four from Bunawan, Agusan del Sur. Now, Leonardo is busy preparing his land for the next planting. He is doing his best to grow his farm business to support all his family's needs.

Leonardo is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. He will use the loan to purchase herbicides and fertilizers. The loan will help improve his harvest.

About CEVI
CEVI helps small business to grow. As well as offering loans, it gives its clients security through its micro-insurance program.

loans.use: To purchase herbicides and fertilizers

loans.name: Ngô's Group

texts.en:
Hà Ngô Thị T. (20203040024) is a 33-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. Hà is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Đồng Thôn 04 (4).

Hà is married and has two very young children. To make a living, Hà operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing furniture-rental services to local community members. Hà has been engaged in this business for more than three years and earns approximately 5,000,000 Vietnamese dong (about $280) a month from these activities.

Hà joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She requests a loan of 5.152.000 VND, which will be used to invest in expanding the business.  This will be the first loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA. Hà plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1. Nguyễn Thị Lý (20203040025) is a 55-year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock.

2.  Hà Thị T. (20203040026) is a 40-year-old female who is also requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock.

3. Trương Thị P. (20203040027) is a 38-year-old female who is also requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock.

4. Dương Thị B. (20203040028) is a 47-year-old female who is also requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock.

5. Trương Thị T. (20203040029) is a 49-year-old female who is also requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide micro-finance services to low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Hà Ngô Thị T.  (20203040024) là 33 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở tH.nh phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Hà là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các tH.nh viên.  Mặc dù mỗi tH.nh viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các tH.nh viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Đồng Thôn 04 (4).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên T. nhập, mà nguồn T. nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ cho T.ê trang thiết bị cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Hà thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Hà kiếm được khoảng 5.000.000 VND.  Hà đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Hà đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ SEDA.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nguyễn Thị Lý (20203040025) là 55 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Hà Thị T. (20203040026) là 40 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


3.  Trương Thị P. (20203040027) là 38 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Dương Thị B. (20203040028) là 47 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


5.  Trương Thị T. (20203040029) là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có T. nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Djénèbou

texts.fr:
Djénèbou K. N. est une veuve de 36 ans qui vit avec ses cinq enfants chez son défunt époux à Wayerma I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso.(république du Mali)
Djénèbou K. N. mène cette activité d’achat et  de vente de bois de chauffe il y a maintenant 4 ans. Elle jouit d’une forte réputation dans cette activité et reçoit beaucoup de commandes surtout en hivernage, mais ses ressources ne peuvent pas lui permettre de les satisfaire. 
C’est ainsi, qu’elle a fait recours à ce deuxième prêt individuel (après avoir correctement remboursé le premier) auprès de l’institution pour acheter, deux chargements de camion “10Tonnes” en bois de chauffe dans les localités environnantes de la ville de Sikasso afin de satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’accroitre.  
Elle est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis environ trois  ans, elle a bénéficié de plusieurs prêts solidaires  avec une association des femmes de son quartier, tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Djénèbou K. N. is a 36-year-old widow who lives with her five children in her late husband's home in Wayerma I, a working-class district of the city of Sikasso (Republic of Mali).  She has been running this business buying and selling firewood for four years now.  She enjoys a great reputation in this business and receives many order, especially during the off-season, but her resources prevent her from filling them.  So then, she resorted to this second individual loan (after having repaid the first one correctly) from the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to buy two "10Tonnes" truck loads of firewood from surrounding towns of the city of Sikasso, so as to satisfy her ever-growing customer base.  She has had an association with Soro Yiriwaso for about three years.  She has benefited from several solidarity loans with a women's association in her area.  All her preceding loans were correctly repaid.  She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA that will be used to help with family expenses, to cover the interest on her loan, and to invest the rest into her business. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es: Isabel tiene 50 años, vive con su pequeña hija de 8 años en su casa propia. Hace 4 años emprendió el negocio de la venta de cervezas en su misma casa, para lo cual Isabel se cerciora de conocer a la persona a quién le vende. Asimismo lleva su producto a diferentes eventos sociales de su localidad. Adicionalmente, vende ropa interior en la feria comercial de su ciudad. Con estas actividades logra solventar los gastos de su familia, por lo que su próxima meta es incrementar su mercadería para a su vez, aumentar sus ventas. Esta es la segunda oportunidad de crédito que tiene con MFP, ella ha demostrado ser puntual en sus pagos y motiva la responsabilidad en las demás integrantes de su banco comunal. El dinero que viene solicitando será destinado a la compra de mayor cantidad de cajas de cerveza y ropa al por mayor, directamente de la fábrica.
texts.en:
Isabel is 50 years old and lives with her 8-year-old daughter. Four years ago, she started selling beer from her home, which has helped her get to know her customers. She also sells beer at various social events in her community. In addition to selling beer, Isabel sells underwear at her local swap meet. This is how she has been able to earn a living for her family. She would like to increase the amount of merchandise she has so she can increase her sales. This is Isabel’s second loan with MFP. She has been punctual with her payments and this in turn motivates other members of her communal bank to be punctual. She will buy boxes of beer wholesale directly from the factory with her loan money.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchanise

loans.name: Wema Group

texts.en:
Grace is a member of the Wema borrower group in Sakina, Arusha. She is 39 year old  woman, she is married and a mother of 5 children. Her children are 20,18,15,12 and 7 years old, she also cares for other 5 dependents.

Grace has owned a food business selling vegetable for 10 years, she works 12 hours a day and  she earns
a monthly profit approximately 300,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Grace`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 500,000 Tsh in order to buy more  vegetable.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Grace hopes to save more money and expand her business.

Hellena is another member of the same borrower group, she requested the amount of 500,000 in order to expand her shop business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetable farm

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie L. lives in the village of Oro Cena, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 42 years old, married and has two school-aged children. Tessie makes a living running a sari-sari (or variety) retail shop where she sells food and other items that people in her community use daily. Tessie has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from her work.

In August, Tessie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and increase her business opportunities. Tessie has applied for a loan of 5,000 PHP to buy new items to sell and expand the range of products she offers her customers. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to improve her family's living standards and provide her children with an education.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy new items to sell to her customers

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Mob

texts.en: Mob M., 26, pictured with her husband, is married with four young children and lives in the Siem Reap province. She is a good housewife living at home and cooking for her family members. Since 2007, her husband has been operating a motor-taxi business to earn a living and is able to make a profit of US$5 every day. Currently, his motorbike is broken so Mob M. is asking for a loan to repair it. The rest of the loan will be used to fix their leaking roof.

loans.use: Repair motorbike and fix leaking roof.

loans.name: Mariano

texts.en:
Mariano is a client of Asociación Arariwa. He is a member of a communal bank that consists 15 neighbors who live in Ccorao, a town that is 30 minutes from Cusco. The group is called Reynita de Belen de Ccorao and named after a virgin of Peru. He is from Ccorao. He is 59 years old and is married. Mariano has 6 children and 5 grandchildren.

Mariano raises cuy (guinea pigs). He prepares various dishes with cuy for tourists from Cusco when they come to buy artisan goods. He even caters government meetings and ceremonies, where he sells 30-40 cuy at one time. Each cuy costs 10-30 soles, which is the equivalent of $3.50 - $7.00 USD each. He earns about 300-400 soles, which is the equivalent of $105 - $140 USD per week. He has worked with Arariwa since 2002. He will use this loan to buy food and medicine for his cuy farm.

The video shows Mariano in one of his smaller cuy pens, where he raises 100 cuy. (The other pen holds 500 cuy.) He says he enjoys his work and that raising so many cuy is "like a sport."

Mariano appreciates and thanks you for the loan and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To buy food and medicine for his guinea pigs

loans.name: Las Pascuas Group

texts.es:
El grupo las Pascuas esta conformado por tres señoras emprendedoras  estas son Martha Lorena T. E., Violeta del Carmen P. L. y Karla Patricia M.. La señora T. E. tiene una pequeña venta y con el crédito piensa invertir en granos básicos y productos de consumo para el hogar.

 
Violeta del Carmen P. L.  desde muy temprano se levanta para abrir su verdulería y Karla Patricia M. vende ropa como camisas, blusas, pantalones, ropa interior, ropa para niños  y trajes. 

Este grupo tiene años de trabajar junto Adim y espera seguir trabajando para seguir progresando y aprovechar las  festividades de estos meses.
texts.en:
The Pascuas group is comprised of three enterprising women; Martha Lorena T. E., Violeta del Carmen P. L., and Karla Patricia M.. T. E. has a small sales business. She will use the loan to buy basic grains and basic consumer products for the home. Violeta del Carment P. L. gets up very early to open her greengrocery. Karla Patricia M. sells clothes likes shirts, blouses, pants, underwear, children’s clothes, and outfits. This group has worked with Adim for years. They hope to continue working to keep progressing and to takes advantage of the festivals in these months.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic grains

loans.name: Digna Adilia

texts.es:
la joven Digna H. tiene 35 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de abarroteria, su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su casa de habitación.
Digna es una persona cristiana y tiene un par de años de haber iniciado con su negocio, nos comento que inicio su pulpería con un capital muy bajo y ahora su negocio ha crecido en gran manera. En estos momentos no esta muy surtido su negocio por eso es que necesita el credito para poder comprar mas mercaderia y asi tener bien surtida su pulperia.
Es casada y tiene hijos los cuales dependen del matrimonio, su esposo se dedica a la agricultura.
juntos salen adelante y contribuyen con los gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
Digna H. is 35 years old and sells groceries out of her home. She is a Christian woman who started this business two years ago with very little capital. Now it has grown tremendously. At the moment, her business is low on inventory so she is requesting this loan to buy more merchandise and keep her store well-stocked. Digna is married and has dependent children. Her husband is a famer and they work together to move forward and help one another with the household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Cresenciana

texts.en:
Cresenciana is a 62-year-old woman, widowed and the mother of four children, none of whom have finished schooling because of poverty, three are at high school level and one is only at elementary level. She lives on the island of Buhangin, Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines.

With her belief and faith to get out of poverty, in 2008 she decided to join ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. During her previous loans, she carefully invested in her sari-sari store business (a small retail store selling different goods) which gives her a reasonable income. Now on her third loan, she proposes to borrow the amount of Php 15,000 pesos as additional capital, again for her sari-sari store. Specifically, the amount will be used to purchase six sacks of rice worth Php 8,400.00, 50 kilos of sugar at Php 2,100.00, 50 bottles of cooking oil at Php 1,000.00, 50 packs of cigarettes at Php 1,300.00, and 50 liters of gasoline at Php 2,000.00 with the remaining Php 200.00 for travel fares. 

She hopes that her business will expand so that they will have savings for future use and dreams of having a successful general store, and also of helping her family to have a good life and to break the cycle of poverty.

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, sugar, cooking oil, cigarettes and gasoline and to pay for travel fares.

loans.name: Glyjean

texts.en:
Glyjean S. is 21 years old. She manages a small rice farm and a piggery. She has a two-year-old child. Her family relies on the income she makes from the pigs and farm. She sells her harvest to rice traders and she sells her pigs to meat traders. The money she makes helps her to buy food, clothing and other basic supplies for her family.

She would like to request a loan of Php 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies, piglets, and feed.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies, piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Bertha

texts.es:
La señora Bertha, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Los Jazmines”, Distrito de Moyobamba, Provincia de Moyobamba, Departamento de San Martín. Es Separada, tiene 60 años y es madre de 06 hijos, todos ya independientes.
Bertha, se dedica a la venta de granos y lleva varios años ejerciendo este tipo de actividad, se encuentra ubicada en el Mercado Central de su Distrito. Poco a poco, fue ahorrando e invirtiendo mas en su negocio y hoy en la actualidad ya es  muy conocida por sus clientes, que día a día, acuden a su puesto a consumir sus productos. 

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, comprará en sacos de cacao, maíz y maní, para luego preparar mantequilla de maní, maíz amarillo, para la preparación de chichas, fréjoles en kilos, racimos de plátanos verdes,  para preparar harina de plátano.
Bertha, se siente muy orgullosa por el trabajo que realiza durante tantos años, el buen producto que vende le ha proporcionado clientela fiel que compra todos los días y es muy conocida en el mercado. Agradace al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por el apoyo incondicional a mujeres como ella.
texts.en:
. Bertha, 60, is a member of the "Los Jazmines" communal bank, which is in Moyobamba district, Moyobamba province, San Martín department. She is separated and the mother of 6 adult children. Bertha has been a grains merchant for several years in her district's central market. Little by little she saved and invested more in her business and today she is very well-known by her customers who visit her daily to buy her products. With this 1000 sol loan she will buy sacks of cocoa beans, corn and peanuts to make peanut butter; yellow corn to make chichas (alcoholic drink made from fermented corn), kilograms of kidney beans, bunches of green bananas to make banana flour. Bertha feels very proud of the work she has done for so many years; the good product she sells has produced regular customers for her that buy daily from her; she is very well-known in the market. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for the unconditional support it gives women like her.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables.

loans.name: Francisco Luis

texts.es:
El señor Francisco Luis González S., tiene una propiedad pequeña donde él se dedica a la siembra de granos básicos como frijol y maíz para consumo y para negocio venta de este mismo producto al momento que saca la cosecha, este tipo de cultivos los realiza  solamente  en épocas de invierno, después de la época de la cosecha él se dedica a comprar este producto en las zonas de la montaña a un precio más bajo que en el mercado de la  cuidad,   la razón para la cual utilizara este financiamiento. Es para comprar 18 quintales de frijol el cual el después venderá a compradores de mercado de la ciudad a un mejor precio del que el adquirió. Este cliente comenzó cultivando granos básicos  únicamente en épocas de invierno, el trabajo lo hacía con ayuda de su familia, el es casado tiene una esposa y 2 hijos uno es mayor  de edad y le ayuda en las actividades de trabajo en el campo a sembrar y cultivar hasta la cosecha de estos granos , este cliente todo el tiempo se ha dedicado a esta actividad de trabajo y actualmente continua haciéndolo, con esto el espera seguir mejorando su actividad de trabajo y poder mantener una forma de trabajo en todo el año ya que después que saca la cosecha no hay trabajo y de esta forma con la compra y venta de granos el espera tener trabajo y una forma de ingresos para él y su familia y así ir mejorando su  nivel de vida.
Don Francisco Luis González S., ha tenido 7 créditos  5 años de trabajar con Ceprodel.
El impacto y beneficios que ha tenido con los financiamientos  es bastante importante ya que le permitieron mejorar sus actividades de trabajo lo que le han dado como resultado tener e ir mejorando su nivel de vida teniendo mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Francisco Luis González S. has a small plot of land where he grows beans and corn both for his own consumption and to sell when he harvests them. He works the land only in Winter. Once harvesting season is over, he buys these products up in the mountains because prices are lower than in the city; this is why he needs financing. He wants to buy 18 quintales (weight measure equivalent to 46 kilos) of beans which he will resell to buyers in the city market at a higher price than what he paid for them. This client began cultivating basic grains just in Winter; he would do the work with his family’s assistance. He is married and has two children, one of whom is an adult and helps him with the field work, to sow and cultivate, until harvest time. He has always been a farmer and continues to be, expecting to continue to improve his work and be able to maintain some kind of work year-round because, once the harvest is in, there is no more work. He hopes, therefore, that buying and selling beans is a way to have income for himself and his family and, thus, continue to improve his quality of life. Francisco Luis González S. has had 7 loans during 5 years of collaborating with Ceprodel. The impact and benefit of the loans have been considerable in that they allowed him to improve his work activities which, in turn, has resulted in a gradual improvement of his living conditions by producing better income.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beans.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en: Wilma P. owns and operates a general store selling a variety of different products in her community. She is 40 years old, married and has four adult children. She is from the village of Canibungan Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Wilma has been in her business for over one year and earns approximately 1,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Wilma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to to purchase products to sell. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to financially support extended members of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Walter

texts.es:
Walter C. B., tiene la edad de 28 años, está en unión libre, y vive con la compañera  y un hijo de un año de edad. El crédito lo quiere para la compra de materiales y artículos para aumentar el inventario de su negocio, el cual consiste en un pequeño bazar. Desea tener un inventario más variado de artículos, para ampliar su negocio y a la vez ofrecer más variedad a los clientes. Hace aproximadamente 2 años que empezó este negocio viendo la necesidad de incrementar el ingreso ecónomico para su hogar. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le han brindado siempre. El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como comerciante.

About FUDECOSUR:
The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org
texts.en:
Walter C. B., 28, is in a common-law relationship; he lives with his partner and a one-year-old son. He wants funding to buy supplies and items to increase the inventory in his business, which is a small store. He wants to have a more varied inventory so that his business can grow while offering his customers a wider variety of articles. He started the business about 2 years ago having realized that he had to do something to increase family income. This is his first loan with FUDECOSUR and he is very happy with the loan terms he has been offered. He hopes to provide his family with improved quality of life and greater economic stability in the future as well as to continue to develop as a person and as a merchant.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock inventory items.

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Ii Group

texts.es:
El comité D. Mujeres Unidas II es un grupo muy activo y el trabajo solidario se nota en cada una D. sus integrantes, ya que todas elL. a parte D. ser compañeras en el Comité son muy buenas amigas.
Todas cuentan con una actividad independiente que les genera ganancia, así como el caso D. la señora Saviana quien después D. integrarse al comité decidió trabajar  vendiendo todo tipo D. lencerías D. distintas  marcas, ella recorre por muchas casas comerciales ofreciendo sus productos y ademas tiene clientes individuales que pagan en cuotas.
Actualmente con el crédito lo destinó  a la compra D. gran cantidad D. lencerías para vender.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Unidas II (Women United II) group is very active, and the women work together well. The support provided by each group member is very clear; as well as being colleagues within the group, they are very good friends. Each woman has her own job which provides an income. For instance, after joining the group, Señora Saviana decided to start a business selling all types and brands of lingerie. She goes to many stores selling her products and also has individual customers who pay in installments. She now wants to use the loan to buy a large quantity of lingerie to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy lingerie

loans.name: Aleyda De Jesus

texts.es: Doña Aleyda, vive en el barrio Memorial Sandino, de edad de 36 años, con una hija el cual estudia, su esposo es cadete de Taxi. La señora Aleyda trabaja desde hace varios años como domestica, para poder apoyar su esposo con los gastos, ya que todo esta caro y hacen falta muchas cosas por hacer en su pequeña casa. Las dificultades en su trabajo es que su salario es poco y el trabajo es mucho. Con este financiamiento quiere cambiar el techo ya que esta en mal estado y desea hacerlo ante del invierno. Comprara materiales de construcción y comenzara la obra. Que será de gran beneficio para su familia en poder tener mejor comodidad. Sus planes es lograr encontrar un trabajo que le paguen mejor para poder ayudarse económicamente. Es por eso para ella es importante la educación de su hija para que logré mejores oportunidades de trabajo.
texts.en:
Aleyda, 36, lives in the Memorial Sandino neighborhood with her daughter, who is a student, and her husband, who is a taxi driver. She has worked as a domestic employee for several years to help her husband meet household expenses since everything is expensive and they still need a lot done to their small house. A problem with her job is that the salary is low and the work load is high. She will use the funds to replace her roof because it’s in poor condition and she wants to replace it before winter. She will buy building materials and supplies to begin the project, which will be of great benefit to her family by providing increased comfort. Her plans are to manage to find a better job where her salary is higher so that she can help herself financially. This is why she considers her daughter’s education so very important: so that she will have better employment opportunities. .

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy zinc metal sheeting.

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen is a widow and comes from Multan, a city famous for its shrines and sweetmeats in Pakistan. Her husband died of a heart attack. She was completely lost but she recovered herself for her children: one son and two daughters. Her husband was the only breadwinner for their family. 

After her husband's death she took over his responsibilities and started selling women's clothes. She purchased the clothes from cities (Faisalabad and Lahore) because of their cheap prices and good quality and sells in her community. Now her business is very famous in her neighborhood and she receives a lot of orders. 

She is applying for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) to purchase clothes in bulk to complete an order on time and earn good profit.

loans.use: Purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Mawulawoe

texts.fr: Cette femme s’est lancée en 2008 dans le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale, elle est très dynamique ce qui fait qu’elle gagne tous les jours de nouveaux clients, actuellement elle fait face à une baisse de son stock, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de divers produits d’alimentation générale. Elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. C’est avec ce qu’elle gagne de son commerce qu’elle contribue financièrement aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This lady began selling food products in 2008. She is very dynamic, which wins her new customers every day. Currently, her inventory is low, and for that reason she would like a loan from WAGES to build up her stock of food products. She is married with four children. With the earnings from her business, she helps to pay household expenses..

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food products

loans.name: Massesebeh Group

texts.en:
These are the members of Massebeh Group. They are small-scale businesspeople in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of SLL 800,000 each to enable them to improve their businesses. With a loan, they will be able to add more goods to their stalls, make more sales and better profits. Consequently, their living standards will improve so that they can better look after themselves and their children.

The leader of this group is Abdul K., pictured on the left. He was born in Magburaka town and is now 55 years old. He is married with eleven children: two are now teachers, eight are in secondary schools and one is in primary school.

Abdul is a motor-mechanic and he has been in this profession for thirty years now. With this loan, he will buy engine oil, tires and other spare-parts to sell.

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo).

loans.use: To buy engine oil, tires and other spare-parts to sell

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Mateo Pumacahua se reúne en la ciudad de Chicheros del departamento del Cusco,  esta ciudad es más conocida por las ruinas Incas que tiene, cuenta la historia que en tiempos pasados cuando aun no era ciudad en lo que ahora son sus calles había la casa del Inca “Túpac Inca Yupanqui”.  Es también muy interesante esta población no sólo por ruinas y el templo, sin por los trajes y costumbres; además de su colorida y concurrida feria dominical. 

Al visitar este banco conversamos con el socio Bernando, es soltero y vive en Chinchero, él se dedica a la elaboración de tejidos  como mantas, fajas y chullos y vende a los turistas que visitan la ciudad, invierte 1000 dólares en los materiales como por ejemplo lana de oveja y lana de alpaca y tintes naturales como la cochinilla, cucamarca, etc. Ya son 8 años que lleva este oficio y le va muy bien, el ser socio de la Fundación le ha ayudado mucho a superarse y hacer que su negocio crezca, con este nuevo crédito surtirá su negocio y va comprar más materiales. El anhelo del socio es viajar al extranjero pues ahí desea vender sus productos.
texts.en:
The Mateo Pumacahua Communal Bank meet in the city of Chinchero in the Cusco department. This city is more known for the Inca ruins that it has, telling the story that in times passed when there was still no city where there are now streets, there used to be the house of the Inca “Túpac Inca Yupanqui”. This population is also very interesting not only for the ruins and the temple, but for the costumes and customs; in addition to its colorful and crowded Sunday fair. On visiting this bank we talk with the member Bernardo. He is single and lives in Chinchero, where he makes knitwear like blankets, belts and chullos (Peruvian hat) and sells these to the tourists that visit the city. He is investing 1000 dollars in materials such as sheep and alpaca wool and natural dyes like conchineal, cucamarca, etc. He has done this for 8 years and it is going well. Being a member of the Foundation has really helped him to better himself and make his business grow. With this new loan he will stock his business and is going to buy more materials. The member's wish is to travel abroad and then he wants to sell his products there.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more materials such as sheep and alpaca wool and natural dyes like cochineal, cucamarca, etc.

loans.name: Dejidmaa

texts.en:
Dejidmaa M. is 46 years old and lives with her three children in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a 'ger', which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her youngest son and daughter are both students. 

Dejidmaa currently operates a small bakery in her town. She started a retail business in 1995 and just recently opened her bakery in early 2010. She makes a variety of breads and baked goods. 

Dejidmaa has found success in her new venture and has increased her working capital to a level exceeding 2,100,000 MNT.  She is a hard-working but easy-going woman who is focused on the future growth of her business. She says, “ I have a plan to expand my business and to create a more efficient workplace in the future.” 

Dejidmaa hopes to continue to grow her business in the future and is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more supplies and products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies and inventory

loans.name: Kea's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Kea P. is 47 years old and is the village bank president having been selected by the sixteen members from Thlok Doung Tum village in Takeo province.  Each member of this group loan will use their part of the loan to support their different businesses, all in hopes of increasing their income to improve life for their families. Mrs. Kea P. is a grocery seller in the local marK. who earns a small income to support her six children. She will use the loan to buy more groceries to enlarge her business. Mrs. Kea P. is widow with six children; three are laborers and one is still at home.  The other two are students and also support their mother with the business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for selling.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 32 years old. He is married and has two children, ages 3 and 7. Both children attend school. He is a farmer from Nkubu town in Eastern Kenya. He has been farming for 12 years and has employed four people from his community. His main products are milk, bananas, beans, green beans, and maize, which he sells to the local market.

His primary challenges have been a lack of market for his green beans, unfavorable market conditions for his bananas, and pests and diseases which affect his crops and animals.

Moses recently completed his second loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 50,000 KES and has requested this loan of 50,000 KES to upgrade his banana farming by purchasing fertilizers and manure. He says that these farm inputs will increase his production and earn him more income that will improve his family's standard of living.

In the future, he plans to purchase a car that will assist him in transporting bananas from his farm in Nkubu to Nairobi town. He says that Juhudi loans are flexible in the sense that they are paid monthly, which gives him ample time to get the money for repayment.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for bananas

loans.name: Djekafo Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Djekafo II sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Dramanebougou, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées par les membres du groupe sont le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, DJENEBA T., la présidente du groupe, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1,3 hectare de petit mil et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 40.000FCFA environ en fin de   campagne.
texts.en:
The six members of the Djekafo II group are married women who are on average 43 years old with 4 children. Most live in polygamous families in Dramanebougou, one of the villages of the Dioïla Prefecture, Koulikoro Region, 2nd Administrative Region of Mali. They have been collaborating with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution in order to better organize their activities leading in to the lean season. They speculate in millet, groundnut and beans. They are on their third group loan; previous loans were repaid on time. With this new loan, Djeneba T., the President of the group, plans to buy supplies, small equipment and to pay for labour costs to maintain about 1.3 hectares of millet and groundnut. The harvest will be sold in the cities of Dioïla and Massigui to a clientele of men and women. She expects to earn about 40,000 francs income by the end of the season.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labour, seeds, fertilizer, herbicide and small equipment

loans.name: Martha Gricely

texts.es:
Martha Gricely, tiene 53 años.  Es soltera y vive con  los hijos.  Tiene 2 hijos, Jacinto y Duval.
 
Martha es un socia de la ventanilla rural “San Jose de los Amarillos”.  Son 23 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican a la agricultura. Esto es el segundo préstamo que ellos realizan en la Cooperativa San José.

Martha se dedica a la agricultura, siembra maíz. Realiza sus compras cada mes en la ciudad de Ventanas y las vende en la misma localidad.

Solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de maíz. Piensa que el crédito es una oportunidad para salir adelante. Sus sueños es tener un terreno propio para construir una casa. Enfrenta desafíos como plagas y enfermedades como la langosta en el cogollo.

Le gusta trabajar en el campo.
texts.en:
Martha Gricely is 46 years old. She is single and she lives with her children. She has 2 children, Jacinto and Duval. Martha is a member of the rural village of San Jose de los Amarillos. There are 23 members in her group and the majority of them are agriculturists. This is the second loan they request through the San Jose Cooperative (Kiva Field Partner). Martha is an agriculturist and she has corn plantations. She makes her purchases every month in the city of Ventanas, location where she sells her products as well. She requests a loan to invest in the purchase of corn seeds. She seeds this loan as an opportunity to get ahead. Her dreams are to have a plot of land where to build a house. The challenges she faces are langosta infestations in her fields. She enjoys working in the fields.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase corn seeds.

loans.name: María Jesús

texts.es:
La Señora María Jesús A. es socia del banco comunal San Pablo, vive en la comunidad de San Pablo que pertenece a la parroquia de Turi, esta comunidad se encuentra a 10 minutos de la ciudad de Cuenca, su gente mayor se dedica a la cría de animales y a la agricultura, mucha de su gente busca en la ciudad  mejores oportunidades de trabajo.

La Señora María se encuentra hace tres años en la banca comunal y está muy contenta  de pertenecer a este 
grupo de mujeres luchadoras, los créditos anteriores le han beneficiado mucho en su negocio. Se dedica a la venta de frutas, es una comerciante ambulante que realiza esta actividad hace 10 años y gracias a este trabajo ha logrado salir  adelante junto a su familia.

Doña María tiene 64 años, es viuda  hace 13 años y tiene 6 hijos de 43, 38, 36, 27, 25, 23 años de edad, sus dos  primeros hijos son solteros y lo que trabajan es  para sus gastos, sus cuatro hijos casados viven de manera independiente. Vive en su casa propia que ya esta viejita por el paso de los años.
  
Su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de más frutas para incrementar su negocio ya que su meta es seguir manteniendo el mismo.
texts.en:
María Jesús A. is a member of the San Pablo Communal Bank. She lives in the San Pablo community, which is in the Turi parrish. This community is ten minutes from the city of Cuenca. Most of the people in the community raise animals and farm. Many people look for better work opportunities in the city. María has been in the communal bank for three years. She is very happy to belong to this group of tenacious women. The previous loans have benefited her business a great deal. She sells fruit as an itinerant salesperson. She has been doing this for ten years. Thanks to this work she has managed to get ahead together with her family. María is 64 years old, and she has been a widow for 13 years. She has six children; ages 43, 38, 36, 27, 25, and 23. Her first two children are single, and they work for their expenses. Her four married children live independently. She lives in her own house, which is old due to the passage of time. She will use the new loan to buy more fruit to increase her business. Her goal is to continue maintaining her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy oranges, coconuts, papayas, pineapples, and bananas, etc.

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia M. is from the village of Solinog Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Emelia is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Emelia owns and operates a retail store selling daily use products such as pancit, sardines, noodles, eggs, biscuits, candies, milk, shampoo, soap and toothpaste. Emelia has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Emelia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Emelia is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken by Emelia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Davy-Herman-Clotaire

texts.fr:
Homme celibataire et père d'un enfant agé de 8ans dont une personne en charge.Il debute son commerce de cafétariat en 2004 avec un capital de 100000frs. ses potentiel clients sont des vendeurs du marché des écoliers et des chauffeurs de taxi.ses recettes sont 10000 à 35000frs par jours.
 ce prêt lui permettra d'acheter des boits de chauffe et du charbon de reserve, des bôite de lait, du sucre, des spaghettis,des boites de matinal et café, du caucisson sec, des pains,des friandises.
IL reserve un bon étallage et acceuil à ses client et ceux en depit des problemes de ravitaillement lié aux moyens financier.
il à pour strategie d'offrir à ses clients des prix hors concurrance.
il aimerait offrir un cadre reposant et proper à ses client ainsi que un quantenaire d'alimentation et une boucherie dans les jours futurs.pour sa famille il veut que ses enfants frequentes dans les plus grandes écoles et améliorer leus condition de vie.
texts.en:
This entrepreneur is a single man, with an 8-year old child and one dependent. He launched his snack stand in 2004, with a starting capital of 100,000 West African Francs. His potential customers are market vendors, school children and taxi drivers. His sales range from 10,000 to 35,000 West African Francs per day.

This loan will allow him to purchase boxes of firewood, and charcoal as well as a supply of milk, sugar, pasta, breakfast foods and coffee, dry sausage, rolls, sweets, etc. He offers his customers a good product selection and service, in spite of financial difficulties with restocking his goods. His strategy is to offer unbeatable prices to his customers. He would like to offer a relaxing and clean environment to his clients and eventually to open an eatery and a butcher shop. As to his family, he would like his children to attend the best colleges and have a better life.

loans.use: Purchasing pasta, milk, sugar, bread, coffee, sweets etc

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
This is Yolanda T., a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is 53 years old, married to Jose T., a retired pensioner, and is the mother to five hardworking young adults. By the grace of God, Melitona has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.
Yolanda operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Yolanda earns a living by purchasing supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at piece rates. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and members of the local community. She earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue to operate her business, she is requesting a loan of 11, 000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Yolanda dreams of renovating her house soon, with the profits from all of her work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. * All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products (such as groceries, toiletries and beverages) to expand her inventory

loans.name: Chu

texts.en: C. Chu Thị is a 59 year-old woman living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. She is married and has five grown-up children. To make a living, C. owns and operates a business selling herbs and spices in her community. C. has been in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000,000 dong (VND) a month. In 2008, C. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. C. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,026,000 VND from SEDA which was used to invest in renovating the business. C. is now requesting a new loan of 8,288,000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her fourth loan from SEDA. C. plans to use additional income to improve the general living conditions of her family. No. 20213050028. About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ====================================== C. Chu Thị (20213050028) là 59 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 5 trẻ ở độ tuổi trưởng thành. Để kiếm sống, C. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh. Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các loại thảo mộc & gia vị trong cộng đồng địa phương. C. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, C. kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND một tháng. Vào 2008, C. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. C. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư đổi mới công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.288.000 VND. Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. C. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh cải thiện điều kiện sống chung của gia đình người vay. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Budi

texts.en:
Budi S. (PK-00251) is a 42-year-old male living in the town of Pejarakan - Singaraja, Indonesia.  He is married and has one infant child.  To make a living, Budi owns & operates a business making & selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community.  Budi has been engaged in this business for over six years and earns approximately 500,000 IDR a month from these activities.

In 2010, Budi joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities.
